title: COVID-19 Vaccines, Testing, and Treatments
description: Dartmouth Health provides COVID-19 vaccine, testing, and treatment information so that you can be better informed.
cleaned_text: Hotline hours: Monday through Friday, 7 am to 5 pm; closed on holidays The updated COVID-19 vaccine is not yet available. We are waiting on approval and recommendations expected from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) this fall. As soon as we have more information available, we will update our website. [Learn more about COVID-19 vaccines on the CDC's website](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/index.html). Booster Shots People who are at higher risk should get a booster dose to continue to have the highest level of protection that the vaccines provide. COVID-19 Testing As of April 1, we are no longer offering COVID-19 testing. At-home antigen tests are available at local retail pharmacies and online. To get a PCR test, please visit your local urgent care center. COVID-19 Treatments There are several therapeutic drugs that are approved by the FDA or that have Emergency Use Authorization to treat or prevent COVID-19. Visiting Our Facilities As a part of our effort to keep patients and staff healthy during COVID-19, our visitor guidelines are frequently changing. Be sure you are aware of the latest policy in effect. Post-Acute COVID-Syndrome Clinic We provide care for patients with Post-Acute COVID Syndrome, also known as [long COVID](/long-covid), at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center. Our multidisciplinary team can oversee evaluation and management of patients with this emerging problem. Long COVID The term long COVID does not necessarily mean that a person is still infected with the virus. It means that they are experiencing troublesome, often debilitating symptoms that last beyond 12 weeks after the acute infection is over.
